jparsec.ephem

Class Ephem

  • java.lang.Object
    • jparsec.ephem.Ephem

  • public class Ephem
extends java.lang.Object
    This class provides accurate ephemeris of any major body in the Solar System. The method getEphemeris(TimeElement, ObserverElement, EphemerisElement, boolean) is the main part of this class, and needs some other methods for different corrections.
    Version:
    1.0
    Author:
    T. Alonso Albi - OAN (Spain)
    See Also:
    Functions, TimeElement, ObserverElement, EphemerisElement, EphemElement

    • Method Detail

      • getEphemeris

        public static EphemElement getEphemeris(java.lang.String body,
                        TimeElement time,
                        ObserverElement observer,
                        EphemerisElement eph0,
                        boolean fullEphem)
                                 throws JPARSECException
        A fast way to perform ephemerides calculations for a given object. This method does not call any Internet service, it resolves objects using only JPARSEC. Source can be a star, deep sky object, or solar system body. For deep sky objects only the equatorial position is returned. Ephemeris properties are modified to perform the ephemerides computation, although the input object is not modified.
        Parameters:
        body - The name of the body.
        time - Time object for calculations.
        observer - Observer object for calculations.
        eph0 - Ephemeris object for calculations. It is not modified.
        fullEphem - True to obtain also instants of rise, set, transit. Refraction at horizon is supposed to be 34', and the angular radius of the object in taken into account.
        Returns:
        The results of the ephemerides.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If the body is not found.

      • getEphemeris

        public static EphemElement getEphemeris(TimeElement time,
                        ObserverElement obs,
                        EphemerisElement eph_in,
                        boolean full_ephem,
                        boolean preferPrecision)
                                 throws JPARSECException
        Calculate planetary (or natural satellite) positions, providing full data. This method applies the adequate planetary algorithm depending if one prefers precision or performance. The ephemeris algorithm and reduction method is changed if required depending on the calculation date and the preference for precision or performance. Full data includes rise, set, and transit times, referred to the current day or the next events in time (if the object is actually below the horizon).

        Natural satellite ephemeris are calculated using the best possible method for the mother planet, with maximum possible precision. JPL DE405 when available (external files supported), and Series96 or Moshier when JPL is not available. The theory used for the satellite will be a specific one for the satellites around the planet (L1, TASS, GUST86, ...) or JPL elliptic elements in case precise ephemeris is not requested or the satellite position can only be calculated in this way.

        Algorithm, method, and frame selected are not changed if the ephemeris is for a star, comet or asteroid, space probe, or artificial satellite.

        Parameters:
        time - Time object containing the date.
        obs - Observer object containing the observer position.
        eph_in - Ephemeris object defining the ephemeris properties.
        full_ephem - True to obtain also instants of rise, set, transit. Refraction at horizon is supposed to be 34', and the angular radius of the object in taken into account.
        preferPrecision - True to prefer precision (only if EphemerisElement.preferPrecisionInEphemerides is also true). In this case the fields algorithm, method, and frame of the ephemeris object will be modified to get the best possible accuracy depending on the available resources. In case this is set to false OR EphemerisElement.preferPrecisionInEphemerides is false the method to be used will be always the Moshier fit to JPL DE404 ephemerides. Preference order for accuracy is JPL DE406/405 (either JPARSEC's file or an external one, if the one selected in Configuration.JPL_EPHEMERIDES_FILES_EXTERNAL_PATH is available), Series96 between 1900 and 2100 for planets, ELP2000 always for the Moon, VSOP87 for Mercury, Mars, and Venus before 1350 B.C., and Moshier in the rest of cases. For both values of this parameter Moshier method will use JPL reduction methods, and the others IAU 2006 algorithms. Frame is ICRF always.
        Returns:
        Ephem object containing full ephemeris data.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - Thrown if the calculation fails.

      • getEphemeris

        public static EphemElement getEphemeris(TimeElement time,
                        ObserverElement obs,
                        EphemerisElement eph,
                        boolean full_ephem)
                                 throws JPARSECException
        Calculate planetary positions, providing full data. This method applies the planetary algorithm selected in the ephemeris object, without considering the value of EphemerisElement.preferPrecisionInEphemerides. Full data includes rise, set, and transit times, referred to the current day or the next events in time (if the object is actually below the horizon). Natural satellite ephemeris are calculated using the best possible method for the mother planet, with maximum possible precision. JPL DE405 when available (external files supported), and Series96 or Moshier when JPL is not available. The theory used for the satellite will be a specific one for the satellites around the planet (L1, TASS, GUST86, ...) or JPL elliptic elements in case precise ephemeris is not requested or the satellite position can only be calculated in this way. Using this method for planets could launch exceptions if the required algorithm is not available in the classpath or it requires external files that cannot be found. For natural satellites no problem will appear, but the algorithm used for the position of the mother planet will give preference to JPL DE406/405 or Series96, using Moshier only if they are unavailable.
        Parameters:
        time - Time object containing the date.
        obs - Observer object containing the observer position.
        eph - Ephemeris object defining the ephemeris properties.
        full_ephem - True to obtain also instants of rise, set, transit. Refraction at horizon is supposed to be 34', and the angular radius of the object in taken into account.
        Returns:
        Ephem object containing full ephemeris data.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - Thrown if the calculation fails.

      • setEphemerisElementAccordingToBodyType

        public static void setEphemerisElementAccordingToBodyType(TimeElement time,
                                          ObserverElement obs,
                                          EphemerisElement eph,
                                          java.lang.String targetName)
                                                   throws JPARSECException
        A quick way to set some properties of an ephemeris element (algorithm, orbital elements set, and target body) according to certain body. This methods searches for a given planet, natural satellite, asteroid, distant body, comet, probe, artificial satellite, or star.

        Please note the availability of certain objects like asteroids and comets depends on certain configuration values in class Configuration. This means a given comet will be available for some years around the reference date of the orbital elements (date given by the time object), but for a different date (time object) the same object could be unavailable in case the ephemerides are expected to be inaccurate.
        Parameters:
        time - Time object.
        obs - Observer object.
        eph - Ephemeris object.
        targetName - Target's name.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If the object is not found.

      • getTopocentricLightTime

        public static double getTopocentricLightTime(double[] geo_eq,
                             double[] topo,
                             EphemerisElement eph)
        Obtain light time distance in days from the position of the object and the observer, taking into account the ephemeris type.
        Parameters:
        geo_eq - Goecentric equatorial coordinates of object.
        topo - Topocentric equatorial coordinates of observer.
        eph - Ephemeris object defining the ephemeris properties.
        Returns:
        Light time in days. Will be null if ephemeris are geometric.

      • DynamicaltoICRSFrame

        public static double[] DynamicaltoICRSFrame(double[] geo_eq)
        Transform coordinates from J2000 mean pole to ICRS frame. From NOVAS package, based on Hilton and Honenkerk 2004, Astronomy and Astrophysics 413, 765-770, EQ. (6) AND (8).
        Parameters:
        geo_eq - Geocentric rectangular equatorial coordinates of the object, mean equinox J2000.
        Returns:
        vector (x, y, z) with the corrected frame.

      • ICRStoDynamicalFrame

        public static double[] ICRStoDynamicalFrame(double[] geo_eq)
        Transform coordinates from ICRS frame to J2000 mean dynamical frame. From NOVAS package, based on Hilton and Honenkerk 2004, Astronomy and Astrophysics, 413, 765-770, EQ. (6) AND (8).
        Parameters:
        geo_eq - Geocentric rectangular equatorial coordinates of the object (ICRS).
        Returns:
        vector (x, y, z) with the corrected frame.

      • FK5toICRSFrame

        public static double[] FK5toICRSFrame(double[] geo_eq)
        Transform coordinates from FK5 to ICRS frame. Based on Hilton and Honenkerk 2004, Astronomy and Astrophysics 413, 765-770..
        Parameters:
        geo_eq - Geocentric rectangular equatorial coordinates of the object, FK5.
        Returns:
        vector (x, y, z) with the corrected frame.

        Parameters:

        vector (x, y, z) with the corrected frame.

      • toOutputFrame

        public static double[] toOutputFrame(double[] eq,
                     EphemerisElement.FRAME input,
                     EphemerisElement.FRAME output)
                              throws JPARSECException
        Transforms a set of rectangular equatorial coordinates (x, y, z) from one frame into another.
        Parameters:
        eq - The equatorial coordinates, in J2000 equinox for FK5, ICRF, and J2000 frames, and in B1950 for FK4 frame.
        input - The input frame.
        output - The output frame.
        Returns:
        The output coordinates.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If the conversion fails, should never happen.

      • eclipticToEquatorial

        public static double[] eclipticToEquatorial(double[] pos,
                            double JD,
                            EphemerisElement eph)
                                     throws JPARSECException
        Transform mean ecliptic geocentric rectangular coordinates to mean equatorial.
        Parameters:
        pos - ecliptic coordinates as an (x, y, z) or (x, y, z, vx, vy, vz) vector.
        JD - Julian day in Terrestrial Time.
        eph - Ephemeris properties.
        Returns:
        An array containing the new coordinates.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - In case JD is outside range a warning is thrown, and in case warnings should be treated as errors an exception will be thrown.

        Returns:

        Throws:
        JPARSECException - In case JD is outside range a warning is thrown, and in case warnings should be treated as errors an exception will be thrown.

      • topocentricCorrection

        public static EphemElement topocentricCorrection(TimeElement time,
                                 ObserverElement obs,
                                 EphemerisElement eph,
                                 EphemElement ephem)
                                          throws JPARSECException
        Performs topocentric correction of right ascension, declination, and distance, and also diurnal aberration, and adds the results to the EphemElement object.
        Parameters:
        time - Time object.
        obs - The ObserverElement that defines observer's position. In case the observer is not on a given body, a clone of the the input ephemerides object is returned.
        eph - Ephemeris object defining the ephemeris properties.
        ephem - The EphemElement to take from and set the results to.
        Returns:
        The EphemElement with the corrected values.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - Thrown if the method fails, for example because of an invalid date or reference ellipsoid.

      • fastTopocentricCorrection

        public static LocationElement fastTopocentricCorrection(TimeElement time,
                                        ObserverElement obs,
                                        EphemerisElement eph,
                                        EphemElement ephem,
                                        double lst)
                                                 throws JPARSECException
        Performs topocentric correction of right ascension, declination, and distance, without diurnal aberration and using approximate trigonometric computations.
        Parameters:
        time - Time object.
        obs - The ObserverElement that defines observer's position. In case the observer is not on a given body, a clone of the the input ephemerides object is returned.
        eph - Ephemeris object defining the ephemeris properties.
        ephem - The EphemElement object with geocentric position.
        lst - The apparent sidereal time.
        Returns:
        The LocationElement with the topocentric values.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - Thrown if the method fails, for example because of an invalid date or reference ellipsoid.

      • deflectionCorrection

        public static double[] deflectionCorrection(double[] vep,
                            double[] ves,
                            double[] vsp,
                            double[] deflector,
                            double relative_mass)
        Correct apparent coordinates for deflection, using an algorithm from NOVAS package, based on Murray (1981) Monthly Notices Royal Astronomical Society 195, 639-648. This correction is usually lower than 1 arcsecond, and can be neglected most of the times. Only for apparent coordinates.
        Parameters:
        vep - Vector from Earth (observer) to the planet (deflected body).
        ves - Vector from Earth (observer) to Sun.
        vsp - Vector from Sun to planet (deflected body).
        deflector - Vector from sun to deflector body. (0, 0, 0) if it is the sun.
        relative_mass - Reciprocal mass of the deflector body in solar units, equals to deflector body mass / Sun mass = 1 for Sun.
        Returns:
        Array containing (x, y, z) corrected for deflection.

      • solarAndPlanetaryDeflection

        public static double[] solarAndPlanetaryDeflection(double[] vep,
                                   double[] ves,
                                   double[] vsp,
                                   Target.TARGET[] additionalBodies,
                                   double jdTDB,
                                   boolean ecliptic,
                                   ObserverElement obs)
                                            throws JPARSECException
        Correct apparent coordinates for solar and planetary deflection, using an algorithm from NOVAS package, based on Murray (1981), Monthly Notices Royal Astronomical Society 195, 639-648.
        Parameters:
        vep - Vector from Earth (observer) to the planet (deflected body).
        ves - Vector from Earth (observer) to Sun.
        vsp - Vector from Sun to planet (deflected body).
        additionalBodies - Additional bodies for the deflection correction. In order of relevance, Jupiter, Saturn, Moon, Venus, Uranus, Neptune. Earth can also be added. The positions of these bodies are calculated using Moshier algorithms. Set to null to use no additional body.
        jdTDB - The Julian day in TDB.
        ecliptic - True if input coordinates are ecliptic, false if they are equatorial.
        obs - The observer object. Can be null for the Earth's center.
        Returns:
        Array containing (x, y, z) corrected for deflection.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - For invalid calculation dates.

      • solarDeflection

        public static double[] solarDeflection(double[] vep,
                       double[] ves,
                       double[] vsp)
        Correct apparent coordinates for solar deflection, using an algorithm from NOVAS package, based on Murray (1981), Monthly Notices Royal Astronomical Society 195, 639-648.
        Parameters:
        vep - Vector from Earth (observer) to the planet (deflected body).
        ves - Vector from Earth (observer) to Sun.
        vsp - Vector from Sun to planet (deflected body).
        Returns:
        Array containing (x, y, z) corrected for deflection.

      • horizontalCoordinates

        public static EphemElement horizontalCoordinates(TimeElement time,
                                 ObserverElement obs,
                                 EphemerisElement eph,
                                 EphemElement ephem)
                                          throws JPARSECException
        Obtain horizontal coordinates (azimuth, altitude) as seen by the observer. Resulting altitude will be apparent, not geometic, if the value of ephemeris type is EphemerisElement.COORDINATES_TYPE.APPARENT. This method requires previous ephemeris calculations, since it only adds azimuth, elevation, and paralactic angle to the Ephem object. The azimuth is considered equal to zero when an object is towards north, and 90 degrees when is towards East. This method also calculates paralactic angle and corrects the magnitud for extinction if this correction is enabled in the configuration.
        Parameters:
        time - Time object.
        obs - Observer object. In case the observer is not on a given body, a clone of the the input ephemerides object is returned.
        eph - Ephemeris object defining the ephemeris properties.
        ephem - Input coordinates.
        Returns:
        EphemElement with horizontal coordinates.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - Thrown if the method fails, for example because of an invalid date.

      • removeRefractionCorrectionFromEquatorialCoordinates

        public static LocationElement removeRefractionCorrectionFromEquatorialCoordinates(TimeElement time,
                                                                  ObserverElement obs,
                                                                  EphemerisElement eph,
                                                                  LocationElement loc)
                                                                           throws JPARSECException
        Removes the refraction correction in equatorial coordinates.
        Parameters:
        time - Time object.
        obs - Observer object.
        eph - Ephemeris object.
        loc - Right ascension and declination referred to the equinox.
        Returns:
        The equatorial position without refraction correction.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If an error occurs.

        Parameters:

        obs - Observer object.

        loc - Right ascension and declination referred to the equinox.
        Returns:
        The equatorial position corrected for refraction.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If an error occurs.

      • getApparentElevation

        public static double getApparentElevation(EphemerisElement eph,
                          ObserverElement obs,
                          double alt,
                          int maxIter)
                                   throws JPARSECException
        Converts to apparent elevation, by inverting method getGeometricElevation(EphemerisElement, ObserverElement, double). The range of elevations that returns a correct value of the apparent elevation depends on the method. For Bennet formulae output is correct up to a geometric elevation of -4 deg. For Yan formulae up to -1 deg, and for numerical integration up to -3 deg.

        This correction is automatically done for apparent coordinates.

        Parameters:
        eph - Ephemeris properties.
        obs - Observer object containing values of pressure and temperature.
        alt - Geometric elevation in radians.
        maxIter - maximum number of iterations. The value is calculated with an accuracy in the milliarcsecond level unles this value is low enough. A good value is 50.
        Returns:
        Apparent elevation in radians.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - For an invalid (null) value of the observing wavelength.

      • getGeometricElevation

        public static double getGeometricElevation(EphemerisElement eph,
                           ObserverElement obs,
                           double alt)
                                    throws JPARSECException
        Converts to geometric elevation using the adequate model depending on the observing wavelength.
        Parameters:
        eph - Ephemeris properties.
        obs - Observer object.
        alt - Apparent elevation in radians.
        Returns:
        The geometric elevation.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - For an invalid (null) value of the observing wavelength.

      • aberration

        public static double[] aberration(double[] geo_pos,
                  double[] earth,
                  double light_time)
                           throws JPARSECException
        Correct position for aberration, including relativistic effects.

        Adapted from NOVAS package. Algorithm based on Murray (1981), Monthly Notices Royal Astronomical Society 195, 639-648.

        Parameters:
        geo_pos - Geocentric position of the body, corrected for light time (body is supposed static).
        earth - Heliocentric (barycentric when possible) position and velocity of Earth.
        light_time - Topocentric light time in days to the source.
        Returns:
        Geocentric coordinates.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - Should never be thrown.

      • removeAberrationCorrection

        public static double[] removeAberrationCorrection(double[] geo_pos,
                                  double[] earth,
                                  double light_time)
                                           throws JPARSECException
        Removes the correction for aberration, including relativistic effects.

        Adapted from NOVAS package. Algorithm based on Murray (1981), Monthly Notices Royal Astronomical Society 195, 639-648.

        Parameters:
        geo_pos - Geocentric position of the body, corrected for light time (body is supposed static) and aberration.
        earth - Heliocentric (barycentric when possible) position and velocity of Earth.
        light_time - Topocentric light time in days to the source.
        Returns:
        Geocentric coordinates without aberration correction.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - Should never be thrown.

      • toOutputEquinox

        public static EphemElement toOutputEquinox(EphemElement ephem,
                           EphemerisElement eph,
                           double JD_TDB)
                                    throws JPARSECException
        Transform previous calculated position in an Ephem object from true equinox of date to true output equinox.
        Parameters:
        ephem - Input Ephem object.
        eph - Ephemeris object with output equinox.
        JD_TDB - Julian date of input results.
        Returns:
        Ephem object.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If an error occurs.

      • toMeanEquatorial

        public static LocationElement toMeanEquatorial(LocationElement trueEq,
                               TimeElement time,
                               ObserverElement obs,
                               EphemerisElement eph)
                                        throws JPARSECException
        Converts apparent equatorial coordinates to mean equatorial referred to the equinox of the input coordinates (reverting the correction for topocentric location and nutation when necessary). This method is accurate except for the Moon, whose mean position as returned by this method can be wrong by about 0.2". Topocentric correction is done in case ephemeris properties are set to topocentric, and aberration/nutation is corrected in case ephemeris are apparent, and diurnal aberration is corrected in case both previous flags are true.
        Parameters:
        trueEq - True position resulting for ephemeris calculation. Distance must be in AU.
        time - Time object used for the computation of the true equatorial position.
        obs - Observer object used for the computation of the true equatorial position.
        eph - Ephemeris object used for the computation of the true equatorial position.
        Returns:
        The mean equatorial location.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If an error occurs.

      • toMeanEquatorialJ2000

        public static LocationElement toMeanEquatorialJ2000(LocationElement trueEq,
                                    TimeElement time,
                                    ObserverElement obs,
                                    EphemerisElement eph)
                                             throws JPARSECException
        Converts apparent equatorial coordinates to mean equatorial referred to the equinox J2000 (reverting the correction for precession, topocentric location and nutation when necessary). This method is accurate except for the Moon, whose mean position as returned by this method can be wrong by about 0.2". Topocentric correction is done in case ephemeris properties are set to topocentric, and nutation is corrected in case ephemeris are apparent, and diurnal aberration is corrected in case both previous flags are true.
        Parameters:
        trueEq - True position resulting for ephemeris calculation. Distance must be in AU.
        time - Time object used for the computation of the true equatorial position.
        obs - Observer object used for the computation of the true equatorial position.
        eph - Ephemeris object used for the computation of the true equatorial position.
        Returns:
        The mean equatorial location for J2000 equinox.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If an error occurs.

      • fromJ2000ToApparentGeocentricEquatorial

        public static LocationElement fromJ2000ToApparentGeocentricEquatorial(LocationElement loc0,
                                                      TimeElement time,
                                                      ObserverElement observer,
                                                      EphemerisElement eph)
                                                               throws JPARSECException
        Converts mean (astrometric) equatorial coordinates to geocentric, apparent equatorial referred to the true equinox of date. This method is not designed to be extremely accurate, although it provides good accuracy for far away objects.

        To obtain the topocentric the topocentricCorrection(TimeElement, ObserverElement, EphemerisElement, EphemElement) method can be called after by creating an ephem object and setting its equatorial position, but check that the distance in that object is set in AU. For true apparent position you can also consider calling correctEquatorialCoordinatesForRefraction(TimeElement, ObserverElement, EphemerisElement, LocationElement).

        Parameters:
        loc0 - Mean (catalog) J2000 position.
        time - Time object.
        observer - Observer object.
        eph - Ephemeris object.
        Returns:
        The apparent equatorial location.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If an error occurs.

      • getRadialVelocity

        public static double getRadialVelocity(TimeElement time,
                       ObserverElement obs,
                       EphemerisElement eph,
                       double[] planetEquatorialPosAndVel)
                                throws JPARSECException
        Returns the radial velocity of a Solar System object respect the observer, or the geocenter in case the ephemeris object is set to geocentric position. No relativistic corrections are applied in this method, and Moshier algorithms are used for the position of the Earth.
        Parameters:
        time - Time object.
        obs - Observer object.
        eph - Ephemeris object.
        planetEquatorialPosAndVel - Geocentric equatorial position and velocity of the object, AU and AU/day, corrected for light-time. Note methods called getGeocentricPosition in classes for ephemerides (JPL, Moshier, etc) don't provide the adequate velocities for this method, to obtain radial velocity for planets use getRadialVelocity(TimeElement, ObserverElement, EphemerisElement).
        Returns:
        Radial velocity measured respect observer in km/s.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If an error occurs.

      • getRadialVelocity

        public static double getRadialVelocity(TimeElement time,
                       ObserverElement obs,
                       EphemerisElement eph)
                                throws JPARSECException
        Returns the radial velocity of a Solar System object respect the observer, or the geocenter in case the ephemeris object is set to geocentric position. No relativistic corrections are applied in this method, and Moshier algorithms are used for the position of the Earth and the target body.
        Parameters:
        time - Time object.
        obs - Observer object.
        eph - Ephemeris object with a planet as target body.
        Returns:
        Radial velocity measured respect observer in km/s.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If an error occurs.

      • getPositionFromBody

        public static LocationElement getPositionFromBody(LocationElement loc,
                                  TimeElement time,
                                  ObserverElement obs,
                                  EphemerisElement eph)
                                           throws JPARSECException
        Transforms the equatorial position of a body as seen from Earth to the location as seen from a given body, rotating to account for the direction of its north pole of rotation.
        Parameters:
        loc - Mean equatorial position from Earth.
        time - Time object.
        obs - Observer object, containing the new body to refer the position as its 'mother body'.
        eph - Ephemeris object containing the equinox of the input location.
        Returns:
        The new location.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If an error occurs.

      • getPositionFromEarth

        public static LocationElement getPositionFromEarth(LocationElement loc,
                                   TimeElement time,
                                   ObserverElement obs,
                                   EphemerisElement eph)
                                            throws JPARSECException
        Transforms the equatorial position of a body as seen from another body to the location as seen from Earth, de-rotating to account for the direction of the north pole of rotation of the mother (original) body. This method uses IAU resolutions, which provides an acceptable accuracy.
        Parameters:
        loc - Equatorial position from a given body.
        time - Time object.
        obs - Observer object, containing the old body as its 'mother body'.
        eph - Ephemeris object containing the equinox of the output location from Earth.
        Returns:
        The new location from Earth.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If an error occurs.

      • initializeEphemObjects

        public static void initializeEphemObjects(TimeElement time,
                          ObserverElement obs,
                          EphemerisElement eph,
                          java.lang.String loc,
                          Target.TARGET target)
                                   throws JPARSECException
        Initializes the main ephemerides objects by setting them to their most common values.
        Parameters:
        time - Time object, will be set to 'now' using computer clock.
        obs - Observer object, will be set to the city or observatory entered as location name.
        eph - The ephemeris object, will be set to apparent, topocentric ephemerides using IAU 2006 algorithms and Moshier planetary theory. The object will be optimized for speed.
        loc - The name of the location for the observer. Can be a city or an observatory.
        target - The target body for the ephemerides object.
        Throws:
        JPARSECException - If the location is not found to be a city nor an observatory.

      • main

        public static void main(java.lang.String[] args)
        For unit testing only.
        Parameters:
        args - Not used.
